questions.text: Identify the labelled structure in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the provided histology slide, the marked structure is a respiratory bronchiole, characterized by a simple cuboidal epitheliumwithout cilia or goblet cells, and containing outpouchings that open into alveoli.
  • Bronchi and bronchiles can be distinguished based on presence of cartilage and glands in bronchi.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
Superfi cial branch of peroneal nerve supplies which of the following muscles?
1.Peroneus brevis
2. Peroneus longus
3.Peroneus tertius
4. Extensor hallucis longus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The superficial peroneal (fibular) nervearises from the common peroneal nerve and supplies:
  • Motor supply:muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg -
    • Peroneus longus
    • Peroneus brevis
  • Sensory supply:skin of the dorsum of the foot (except the first web space, which is deep peroneal nerve).

questions.text: All of the following are a boundary of Hepato-Cystic triangle EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Hepato-Cystictriangle is an important surgical landmark during cholecystectomy.
  • Boundaries:
    • Medial:Common hepatic duct (CHD) (Option C ruled out)
    • Lateral:Cystic duct (Option A ruled out)
    • Superior:Inferior border of the liver (Option D ruled out)
  • Contents (within the triangle):
    • Cystic arteryand sometimes lymph nodes(Lund's node), veins, accessory ducts.
  • The Calot's triangle lies entirely within the hepatocystic triangle and is Bounded by:
    • Cystic duct(laterally)
    • Common hepatic duct(medially)
    • Cystic artery(superiorly)

questions.text: During cleft lip surgery, which muscles are mainly repaired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In cleft lip, the main deformity is due to disruption of the orbicularis oris muscle, which normally encircles the mouth and provides lip competence.
  • During cleft lip repair, the primary surgical goalis realignment and reconstruction of the orbicularis oris across the cleft to restore lip continuity, function, and aesthetics.
  • Other muscles like levator labii superioris, orbicularis oculi, and masseterare not primarily involved in the defect.

Explanation of other options:

Levator labii superioris (Option A):

  • Function: Elevates the upper lip.
  • Location: Arises from infraorbital margin → inserts into upper lip.
  • Role in cleft lip: May be secondarily affected due to abnormal attachment, but not the primary muscle repaired.

Orbicularis oculi (Option C):

  • Function: Encircles the orbit, closes the eyelids.
  • Location: Around the eye.
  • No role in cleft lip deformity or its repair.

Masseter (Option D):

  • Function: Elevates the mandible (mastication muscle).
  • Location: Lateral surface of the mandible.
  • Completely unrelated to lip formation or cleft lip correction.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved in Olfaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hypoglossal nerve is the cranial nerve XII which is a pure motor nerve that innervates the muscle of tongue, except the palatoglossus.
  • It has no anatomical or functional role in the sense of smell.

Explanation of other options:

Trigeminal Nerve (Option A):

Although smell itself is mediated by the olfactory nerve (CN I), the trigeminal nerve carries somatosensory sensations (burning, cooling, irritation) from the nasal mucosa (e.g., ammonia, menthol, chili). Thus, it contributes to the overall perception of odors.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) (Option B): It provides taste sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue and carries visceral sensations from the oropharynx. Works with olfaction to perceive flavor, though not pure smell.

Vagus nerve (CN X) (Option D): Provides taste sensation from the epiglottis and pharynx. Contributes to chemosensory input that combines smell and taste

questions.text: Which movement is produced by the muscle attached at the marked point?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the image, the marked structure is the lateral pterygoid plate, which serves as the attachment for the lateral pterygoid muscle. The main action of this muscle is to draw the mandibular condyle and articular disc forward, thereby producing depression of the mandible (mouth opening).
  • Assisted by suprahyoid muscleswhen the hyoid bone is stabilized.
  • The lateral pterygoid musclehas two heads.
    • The superior head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone and inserts into the pterygoid fovea. It is supplied by the nerve to the lateral pterygoid, a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve (CN V₃), with separate branches to each head. Its primary action is to stabilize the articular disc during mandibular closing and to help prevent posterior displacement during clenching.
    • The inferior head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and inserts into the capsule and articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. It is also supplied by the lateral pterygoid nerve of CN V₃. Acting bilaterally, it protrudes and assists in depressing the mandible for mouth opening, while unilaterally it moves the mandible contralaterally, producing side-to-side excursions.

Explanation of other options:

Elevation (Option A):

  • Muscles: Masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid.
  • Function: Closes the mouthby raising the mandible.

Retraction (Option C):

  • Muscles: Posterior fibers of temporalis, deep part of masseter, and geniohyoid.
  • Function: Pulls mandible backwardafter protrusion.

Rotation (Option D):

  • In TMJ, 'rotation' refers to the initial hinge movementof the condyle within the mandibular fossa during the first 20° of mouth opening.
  • This is part of depression but not the primary action of the muscle marked.

questions.text: The muscle attaching to the highlighted area performs which of the following function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The marker in the image is pointing towards the dorsolateral surface of the sacral bone. The muscle attached in the marked area is the gluteus maximus and its action is abduction at hip.
  • Origin
    • Posterior surface of the ilium, behind the posterior gluteal line
    • Posterior superior iliac crest
    • Dorsal surface of sacrum and coccyx(inferior part)
    • Sacrotuberous ligament
  • Insertion
    • Primarily into the iliotibial tract (fascia lata)
    • Partly into the gluteal tuberosityon the posterior femur
  • Structure
    • Large, thick, quadrilateral muscle forming the bulk of the buttock
    • Covers most of the posterior pelvis
  • Nerve Supply
    • Inferior gluteal nerve(roots L5, S1, S2)
  • Blood Supply
    • Inferior and superior gluteal arteries
    • First perforating branchof the profunda femoris artery
  • Actions
    • Chief extensor of the hip jointessential for:
      • Rising from sitting
      • Maintaining upright posture
    • Additional actions:
      • Lateral rotation of the thigh(Option A ruled out)
      • Abduction of thigh (via upper fibers)
      • Assists tensor fasciae latae in stabilizing the knee through the iliotibial tract
    • Provides support to hip and kneewhen slightly flexed (Option B and D ruled out)
  • Functions as an antigravity muscle

questions.text: Pick the right options from the image below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The marked structures are:
    1. Ureter (C)- Muscular tube carrying urine from the kidney to the urinary bladder.
    2. Seminal vesicle(B)- Paired gland that secretes fructose-rich fluid forming a major part of semen.
    3. Prostate (D)- Male gland encircling the urethra that secretes alkaline fluid aiding sperm motility.
    4. Vas deferens (ductus deferens) (A)- Muscular tube that transports sperm from the epididymis to the ejaculatory duct.

questions.text:
The deep branch of the ulnar nerve supplies which of the following muscles ?
1)Flexor carpi ulnaris
2)3rd lumbrical
3)Opponens digiti minimi
4)Fourth Dorsal interossei
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The deep branch of ulnar nerve supplies the third lumbrical, opponens digiti minimi and the fourth dorsal interossei.Flexor carpi ulnaris is supplied by the ulnar nerve in the forearm before it divides.
  • The ulnar nerve arises from the ventral rami of C8 and T1 and runs downwards with the brachial artery and descends on the back of medial epicondyle of humerus where it can be palpated.
  • Ulnar nerve course and branches:
    • Roots:Ventral rami of C8-T1.
    • Arm:Descends alongside the brachial artery; passes posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus (palpable here).
    • Forearm:Enters between the two heads of flexor carpi ulnaris.
      • Motor branches:to flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus.
      • Cutaneous branches:
        • Dorsal cutaneous branch→ medial half of dorsum of hand.
        • Palmar cutaneous branch→ medial one-third of palm.
    • Wrist/Hand:At the distal border of the flexor retinaculum, divides into:
      • Superficial branch:supplies palmaris brevis and provides digital branches to the medial 1½ fingers, including nail beds up to the DIP joints.
    • Deep branch:motor to most intrinsic hand muscles (not included in your text, but clinically relevant).
  • Motor Nerve supply by Ulnar nerve at different levels:

questions.text: Pain from dural irritation in the indicated area is typically referred to which location?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The structure indicated in the image is the posterior cranial fossa. Inflammation of its dura mater can cause referred painradiating to the back of the head and neck.(Option A, C and D ruled out)
  • The cranial dura materreceives its primary innervation from branches of all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve namely:
    • Ophthalmic division (V1)- Tentorial branch
    • Maxillary division (V2)- Nervus meningeus medius
    • Mandibular division (V3)- nervus spinosus
  • The posterior cranial fossa is supplied by C2-C3 fibers via the hypoglossal and vagus nerves to the dura and vessels. Since the overlying skin of the back of the head and neck is innervated by the greater (C2) and third occipital (C3) nerves, dural inflammation produces referred pain in these regions.

Explanation of other options:

Ear (Option A): The external ear receives sensory fibers from the auriculotemporal nerve (V3), auricular branch of vagus (Arnold's nerve), and glossopharyngeal nerve.Thus, ear pain is not typically due to posterior fossa dural irritation.

Vertex (Option C): Pain over the vertex region could be stress headache or occipital neuralgia and referred pain here could arises from supratentorial dura supplied by the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (V1)

Mouth (Option D): Pain in the mouth and pharynx is associated with glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and trigeminal (CN V2/V3) innervation, not dura of the posterior fossa.

questions.text: What effect does the depicted cell cluster have on the surrounding cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image depicts a histological section of the islets of Langerhans, which can regulate neighboring cells through paracrine signaling.
  • The endocrine pancreasconsists of multiple small, rounded clusters of cells scattered within the exocrine tissue. These clusters, known as islets of Langerhans, are composed of polyhedral cells with lightly stained cytoplasm. Each islet is encased by a thin layer of reticular connective tissue, which separates it from the surrounding acini, and is extensively vascularized by a dense network of capillaries.
  • While islet hormones help maintain overall systemic balance, they also play a key role locally by using paracrine signalingto modulate the activity and survival of neighboring islet cells.
  • In paracrine signaling, the chemical messengers secreted by a cell act only on neighboring target cells. Within the islets, the close arrangement of endocrine cells and their rich vascular network support this local signaling system through short-range diffusion, direct communication via gap junctions, and circulation within nearby capillaries.

Explanation of other options:

Portal vein (Option A): This refers to endocrine signaling, where secreted hormones enter the bloodstream (like via the hypothalamo-pituitary-portal system) and act on distant organs.

Transformation from epithelial to mesothelial (Option C): This is a cellular differentiation process, not a signaling effect on surrounding cells.

Nerve mediated (Option D): This implies neurocrine signaling, where nerve terminals release neurotransmitters to affect adjacent cells (muscle, gland, or another neuron).
